For any Brits here, I mean public in the American sense, which are of course our state schools, even though we don't have states.:p
 
 People keep mentioning this issue. Is there actually a public school where people are not allowed to openly pray at certain times (so not in the middle of a silent exam)?
 
 Personally, I think if a kid wants to pray, then so be it: let them pray. However I think it should also be voluntary and not enforced, nor frowned upon if a child does not pray. It's always seemed a non-issue to me,a s I assumed just about all public schools are like this (well, bar the frowning part).
 
 -Wez

 Kids can pray on their own time at school if they like, that's not a problem. I think I did hear of some cases where some teacher tried to prevent it, but the ACLU took the case and won on freedom of religion grounds. OF course they can't prey if it would disturb class or anything like that.
 
 The debate is generally over forced prayer. Things like have the principal get on the PA and recite a prayer, and everyone is either supposed to join in or sit there looking like an outcast. That's a no-no.
Captain America banned

I think they should just let religion die a dignified death and quit prolonging the inevitable. It would be kind of hard, in this day and age, for the kids to take their education seriously with the schools endorsing myth and fairy tales.
 
 How could you expect a kid to believe a history or science teacher if the schools mixes facts with Santa Claus type myths and superstitions?
 
 If you want to be religious and brainwash your kids accordingly, fine. After all they are your kids. But keep it out of our schools. Do it at home. Or in a church house, I don't care. Just don't tread on me.
Wez

You can be strongly religous and accept evolution and history as it is. Science and history don't have to clash with religous beliefs.
 
 -Wez

You can be strongly religous and accept evolution and history as it is. Science and history don't have to clash with religous beliefs.

 Can't have both and remain valid. emoticon_xdonno

I'm with the Captain here. In truth religion and science cannot co-exist. It appears to because we are very capable of deceiving ourselves. Religion states "I know", science says "I don't know so let me look." Religion is based on a set of definite authoritative tenets. Science is based on hypothesis and testing. 
 
 I think you maybe mistaking spirituality for religion. Spirituality says "There are things going on here beyond my ability to comprehend". That is inline with science.

Very well, spirituality then.:p
 
 When I said "religion", I meant religous beliefs. These can change and adapt,

I just love dialog with Wez. Posters take notice. This is how two gentlemen debate in simple terms.
 
 Wez, I'll try harder to make my point. In our schools, we have to offer education based in fact, as best we know it. Mathmatic constants. Physics and indisputable laws of nature. We cannot teach a child in one class that constants are constants and then send him to another class and fill their impressionable minds with myths and superstitions as if they are factual as well.
 
 Endorsing prayer is endorsing religion. Religion is based on faith. Faith that a man can raise a stick and the oceans part. Faith teaches us that water can miraculously turn into wine. Faith teaches us that you can be deader than a doornail, and then suddenly come to life and ascend into the clouds with trumpets blaring.
 
 Faith is a direct contradiction to fact in far too many cases. I don't see how we could possibly mix the two and maintain any educational credibility.
 
 I get what your saying though. The other day, my financial advisor came over to assist me in transferance of some stocks. I trust this man with my money. He is a man of logic (I thought.) Then, out of the blue, he started talking about how Catholism is the "true faith" and all that other mumbo jumbo that goes with it.
 
 I now have second thoughts about letting this person, who I once thought was a pretty sharp guy, control my money when he professes to believe in religious delusions.
Jo Bennett

I don't think there is as much of a dichotomoy as you make out. After all, we send students from science and maths to history and sociology, and english literature, without difficulty. I think kids are smarter than you think when it comes to knowing what is proven fact and what is a matter of opinion or belief.
sinjin

 If you can't accept that a very intelligent person could embrace religion you're not one.

 People keep mentioning this issue. Is there actually a public school where people are not allowed to openly pray at certain times (so not in the middle of a silent exam)?
 
 Personally, I think if a kid wants to pray, then so be it: let them pray. However I think it should also be voluntary and not enforced, nor frowned upon if a child does not pray. Wez, I don't see how anyone can stop a student from praying in the midst of an exam or wherever, as long as they are doing so silently. How the devil would anyone know that particular person was praying unless that person made a big fuss and wanted everyone to know that he or she was holier than the others and spent his or her time in prayer?
 
 In fact, in nonschool time, such as at meals, I don't see why someone couldn't mumble a word or two of grace over one's food, as long as that one didn't scream it in everyone's ear.
 
 I can't understand all this fuss and thunder over prayer.
Kronus

Faith is a direct contradiction to fact in far too many cases. I don't see how we could possibly mix the two and maintain any educational credibility.
 

 
 I think you've been spending too much time around creationists. I admit that they do put faith over fact. However, that's not the case with most religious people. Most people of faith are perfectly capable of using fact where it applies (the everyday world) and just using faith where it's approriate (belief in an afterlife, faith that good will win, etc). The number of people who deny reality in favor of faith are a minority. A loud, annoying minority, but a minority none the less. Don't judge all faith by them. They're blind, most people aren't. It's just that the one's that aren't don't stick out as much as the wackos, so you don't know that they're there.
Howard Beale

Captain is right here.
 
 The establishment clause reads:
 
 Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion, or prohibiting the free exercise thereof.
 
 Note that is does NOT say the establishment "of a religion", but rather, the establishment "of religion" -- Religion being:
 
 (1) The service and worship of God or the supernatural 
 (2) Commitment or devotion to religious faith or observance 
 (3) A personal set or institutionalized system of religious attitudes, beliefs, and practices
 
 So it seems that what the clause requires is that Congress not participate in the establishment on any concept involving commitment or devotion to religious faith or observance as well as not participating in support of the concept of a personal set of institutionalized system of religious attitudes, beliefs or practices. It also says that Congress can't stop anybody who wants to engage on any form of that practice.
jyoshu

Religion and science can co-exist, or do you have proof to the contrary? Specific Church teachings/members/actions do not constitute religion as a whole.
 
 -Wez

 
 I'm with you on this one. Only in recent times have people gotten this idea that religion and science can't co-exist. Originally, religion and learning went hand-in-hand. It's no accident that many of the oldest and most prestigeous universities had Christian roots. (Harvard, for instance.) Some of the greatest scientists in history were religious. Here are a few:
 
 Blaise Pascal
 Robert Boyle
 James Prescott Joule
 Rene Descartes 
 Lord Kelvin
 James Clerk Maxwell
 George Washington Carver
 Isaac Newton 
 Michael Faraday 
 Gregor Mendel 
 Max Planck 
 Johannes Kepler 
 Galileo Galilei 
 
 
 Heck, even Einstein recognized the impossibility of non-created universe. And he seemed to know they should go hand-in-hand . . .
 
 "Science without religion is lame, religion without science is blind." --Einstein
Ooaman

Wez, I don't see how anyone can stop a student from praying in the midst of an exam or wherever, as long as they are doing so silently. How the devil would anyone know that particular person was praying unless that person made a big fuss and wanted everyone to know that he or she was holier than the others and spent his or her time in prayer?

 Jesus says the exact same thing...not to make a big show of your praying. No one should, in the Christian faith that is, go and make a big deal about their praying. Wouldn't a belief in an Almighty God suggest that God can hear what ever voice you pray in?
 
In our schools, we have to offer education based in fact, as best we know it. Mathmatic constants. Physics and indisputable laws of nature. We cannot teach a child in one class that constants are constants and then send him to another class and fill their impressionable minds with myths and superstitions as if they are factual as well.

 Do you think that religion shouldn't be taught in a Social Studies class? Part of Social Studies is to learn about other cultures and their histories. Religion is one of the things that define different cultures and shape their history. Look at the Middle East. Besides all of the political messes over their over the decades (and into centuries) one of the main things about the cultures over there is the religion. Why is there so much conflict between the differnet cultures over there, because of their religion (and the political part I mentioned earlier.) Or what about all the Ancient cultures along the Mediteranian Sea. One of the things that defined Ancient Greece besides sports and drama was their religion. If you don't study religions at least in Social Studies then you can't really learn anything.
 
How could you expect a kid to believe a history or science teacher if the schools mixes facts with Santa Claus type myths and superstitions?
Actually, there was a real St. Nick. I believe he was the patron Saint of Turkey. (I'm not Catholic so I don't know this for sure or how it works.) But what he did was go out and throw coins to a man who had very little money and might have had to sale his three daughters into slavery/prostatution. By this St. Nick doing this, the man was able to get by without saleing his daughters. But this was back at least during the middle ages if not well before and probibly looked nothing like the modern day Hallmark Santa Claus. Just a little history lession for everyone. :) 
 
After all, we send students from science and maths to history and sociology, and english literature, without difficulty.
But wait a minute. Isn't English Literature (or any kind of literature for that matter) fiction with no real fact to them that can be proven? If anyone says that there should be no religion subject at all in school should also try to stop students from reading English Lit (or what ever kind of lit.) That sure would have made my Senior year of English breeze by better. :p 
 
 Anyway, on the subject of prayers in school, I believe that all students should have the right to pray. No one said that a person has to be abnauxous when they pray (as I said before, especially Jesus said that.) I do not think they have to get up and drop to their knees and make a big deal out of it. I do not think students should be forced to say a prayer. Thats one reason why we have "Meet You At The Pole" in this country anyway so students can get together and pray by choice. No one ever had to go to that. To deny anyone the right to pray is to deny them the 1st ammendment. (I'm studding journalism. I'm aware of the 1st ammendment.) For anyone not in the USA, the 1st Amend. is the right to free speech and free religion. Enough said, enough said.
Iuris
Religion and Science actually can coexist. All one needs are words like "metaphorical", "parable" and similar.
Howard Beale

Ooaman:
 
 You are misrepresenting Captain America's position (and mine). You're putting up straw men and then arguing with them. Teaching history that includes various religious movements is in no way teaching religion, and I think you know that. 
 
 Teaching that some of the ancient Greeks believed in oracles (the most famous being the Oracle of Delphi) whom they believed spoke with the Gods would be accurate, but if a student asked if there was any evidence that these Oracles really did speak with the Gods, the teacher would have to say no there is no evidence except the writing of the people that believed it and there is no empirical proof to support their belief. 
 
 Teaching that there were Jewish tribes that believed that God spoke to some of their leaders and did various things would be accurate, but if a student asked if their was any evidence that God spoke to any of these guys, the teacher would have to honestly answer, no there is no evidence of that other than things written by the guys themselves and there is no empirical proof to support their belief. 
 
 You could also teach that there was a Christian movement 2000 years ago by people who believed that Jesus Christ was God, but if a student asked if there was any evidence that this guy Jesus Christ was God, the teacher would honestly have to say, no there is no evidence except writings by the guys who believed it and there is no empirical proof to support their belief. 
 
 You could teach that there arose a movement around 600 AD that is called Islam and is based on their scripture called the Qu'ran which they believed was dictated to their prophet Mohammad by the angel Gabriel, but if a student asks if the Qu'ran was really dictated to Mohammad by the angel Gabriel, the teacher would have to honestly answer, no there is no evidence except the writings of the guy(s) who wrote the book and there is no empirical proof to support their belief.
 
 And you could also teach that there developed a Christian movement that put together a bunch of old writings including the Torah into one book called the Bible today and that they believed that the Bible was the written word of God, but if a student asked if there was any evidence that God wrote the Bible, the teacher would honestly have to say, no there is no evidence except writings by the guys who put the book together and there is no empirical proof to support their belief.
 
 Do you think that it is a problem that this would not be allowed to be taught in public schools in this country even though it is historically accurate?
Wez

Wez, I'll try harder to make my point. In our schools, we have to offer education based in fact, as best we know it. Mathmatic constants. Physics and indisputable laws of nature. We cannot teach a child in one class that constants are constants and then send him to another class and fill their impressionable minds with myths and superstitions as if they are factual as well.

 Teaching religion isn't teaching, for example, "God created the Earth in 7 days", it's teaching "Some Christians blieve that God created the Earth in 7 days". The teaching of religous beliefs, as religous beliefs and not as facts/science is fine imo.
 
 
Wez, I don't see how anyone can stop a student from praying in the midst of an exam or wherever, as long as they are doing so silently. How the devil would anyone know that particular person was praying unless that person made a big fuss and wanted everyone to know that he or she was holier than the others and spent his or her time in prayer?

 I agree, but I meant said prayer, ie: spoken out aloud. Sorry for confusion.
 
 -Wez
Howard Beale

Wez:
 
 
Teaching religion isn't teaching, for example, "God created the Earth in 7 days", it's teaching "Some Christians blieve that God created the Earth in 7 days". The teaching of religous beliefs, as religous beliefs and not as facts/science is fine imo.
I think the point is that if you teach about what some Christians believe then it is only fair to teach that some Hindus believe blah, blah, blah..., some Buddhist's believe blah, blah, blah..., some Zoroastrians believe blah, blah, blah..., some Apache believe blah, blah, blah... That is done. In colleges and universities. It is called comparative religion. If students are interested, they can take courses in it, if they are not, they don't have to.
Captain America banned

If you can't accept that a very intelligent person could embrace religion you're not one.

 
 Perhaps you are right and I do not confess to be the smartest fellow on two legs. I do find it puzzling how an otherwise intelligent person can profess to follow ideas that I know to be outlandish poppycock.
 
 But life is full of mystery and I suppose I'll just accept the beauty in that. I am not saying that I would feel uncomfortable fishing in a boat with someone who believes in what I consider to be myth and superstition. On the contrary. Some of my dearest friends are religious in their own way. But when it comes to someone who has control of my hard earned dollars, I'd prefer someone who is not delusional in any regard.
 
 Maybe when it is all said and done, I may find out that I was the dummy all along. I don't know. But for now, all I have to work with is logic and the dictates of reason. emoticon_idea And there really is no room within those parameters for entertaining serious contemplation of all that religious mumbo jumbo. That time could be better spent in my opinion.
jyoshu

Wez:
 
 I think the point is that if you teach about what some Christians believe then it is only fair to teach that some Hindus believe blah, blah, blah..., some Buddhist's believe blah, blah, blah..., some Zoroastrians believe blah, blah, blah..., some Apache believe blah, blah, blah... That is done. In colleges and universities. It is called comparative religion. If students are interested, they can take courses in it, if they are not, they don't have to.

 
 But we are talking about science as a context. One could sum all these religious up and say "many people beleive, based on religion, that the earth was created."
 
 Heck, considering that science WAS heavily influenced by religion for centuries, I don't see how someone can honestly teach science without pointing that out. Why should a science teacher have to not mention what was the prevailing view before Darwin?
 
 I tend to agree with Wez. We can take this too ridiculously far.
 
 If you are talking about schools that teach "the earth was created" AS science, I don't think you'll find too many public schools that would do that anymore.

But we are talking about science as a context. One could sum all these religious up and say "many people beleive, based on religion, that the earth was created."
 
 Heck, considering that science WAS heavily influenced by religion for centuries, I don't see how someone can honestly teach science without pointing that out. Why should a science teacher have to not mention what was the prevailing view before Darwin?

As long as the teacher can also say that there is no scientific proof of to back it up, I have no problem. It is, after all, science class we are talking about.

Wez:
 
 I think the point is that if you teach about what some Christians believe then it is only fair to teach that some Hindus believe blah, blah, blah..., some Buddhist's believe blah, blah, blah..., some Zoroastrians believe blah, blah, blah..., some Apache believe blah, blah, blah... That is done. In colleges and universities. It is called comparative religion. If students are interested, they can take courses in it, if they are not, they don't have to.

 I think the largest religions (Christianity, Islam etc.) should be taught about a bit, while the smaller ones can be ignored till later on in the education system. Religion, as a whole, has had, and still has, such a huge effect on society and the world we live in that it's become, imo, essential to at least give students some background knowledge on the main religions. It doesn't have to be taught for any spiritual reasons imo.
 
 
And seeing that religion has punished scientist for their work, why should scientists teach religion?

 Religous people have, but that shouldn't reflect upon religion as a whole.
 
 -Wez

 In other words, do not teach Shakespeare in a science class. It's fiction. It's art. It's theatre. Make believe. NOT science. Not math. Those are real.
 
 Students should be taught the difference between reality and fiction. Or have the sense to know the difference.
